channel.title: Stories from gizmodo.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best gizmodo.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: A Woman's Breast Implants Saved Her Life From A Gunshot
item.description: Doctors say a woman's silicone breast implants deflected what could have been a fatal bullet, stopping it from reaching her heart. Amazingly, this is not the first time such a thing has been reported in the medical literature.

item.title: Where Did All The Antimatter Go? Scientists Are Closer To Finding Out
item.description: Particle physicists have released the results of a decade-long search, taking us a crucial step closer toward understanding where all of the universe's antimatter has gone.

item.title: Telemedicine Is Not Enough
item.description: It's 2020, and millions of Americans — now bound to their homes — still don't have reliable internet access. In a pandemic, that's a public health crisis.

item.title: IT Workers At Hollywood Reporter and Billboard Vandalize Website After Getting Laid Off
item.description:
"Fat drunk and stupid is no way to go through life…
#SavingABuckAtYourExpense," the (quickly deleted) post read, in part.

item.title: How This Dubious 'Doctor' Became 'The Most Quoted Human On The Planet'
item.description: Steve Maraboli has spent the last two decades building an online empire of self-mythology — and it's almost entirely false.

item.title: Astronomers Spot The Brightest Supernova Ever Recorded
item.description: Back in 2016, a telescope spotted a supernova flaring so brightly that it far outshone its own galaxy. The exploded star continued emitting radiation for more than 1,000 days, unleashing more energy than any supernova previously documented. But that's only the start of the story.

item.title: The Coronavirus Death Count Will Be A New Battle In The Culture Wars
item.description: As parts of the United States settle in for what may be the worst weeks of their local COVID-19 outbreaks, a familiar refrain is sure to emerge.

item.title: The Universe Might Be Expanding Like A Lumpy Balloon
item.description: Is the universe's expansion the same everywhere? New research suggests it's not — which could have huge implications for our understanding of the cosmos.

item.title: A New False Memory Study Suggests People Can't Tell What's Real
item.description: A new study is the latest to show how indistinguishable false memories are from real ones. People who watched someone else recount a supposed recollection were unable to tell that the memory was false with any better accuracy than chance, the study found.

item.title: Hawks' Forbidden Love Results In A Rare Hybrid
item.description: She was a common black hawk. He was a red-shouldered hawk. They weren't in the same genus, let alone the same species, and they normally don't even live in the same part of the continent. But in a strange twist of fate, none of that mattered: It was love at first screech.

item.title: NYC Bans Zoom In Classrooms Following Security Failures
item.description: As reports of security issues surrounding the video conferencing app Zoom continue to mount and accounts of "video-bombing" grow increasingly disturbing, New York City has taken an extreme measure.

item.title: NYC May Temporarily Bury Coronavirus Victims In A Public Park
item.description: The ongoing nightmare of coronavirus has made commonplace what was once unthinkable, a growing list of eroded norms that now includes potentially burying the staggering number of recently deceased New Yorkers in the city's public parks.

item.title: Apple Accidentally Reveals Unreleased AirTags In YouTube Video
item.description: Apple has seemingly foiled its characteristically tight-lipped approach to new product launches by evidently mistakenly confirming one in an unrelated YouTube tutorial on its support channel.
item.kicker: OOPS FOR THEM, GOOD FOR US

item.title: Man Tries To Ram Train Into US Navy Hospital Ship, Doesn't Even Come Close
item.description: Train engineer Eduardo Moreno told a responding California Highway Patrol officer that he believed the hospital ship USNS Mercy — which the US military deployed to the region as part of relief efforts — was part of some kind of conspiracy

item.title: How to Improve Your Wifi Speeds When Everyone's Home
item.description: Chances are, your home internet is under a lot more strain than normal at the moment: With schools and workplaces temporarily closing all across the globe, you might well be fighting with your family or your housemates for any available bandwidth. If you want to limit buffering and maximize speeds, we've got a few tips to consider.

item.title: Why Do Physicists Keep Finding New States Of Matter?
item.description: In reality, physicists know about many states of matter — the number is likely in the thousands. And they keep finding new ones. There are probably millions of potential states to find.

item.title: Van Gogh Painting Stolen Amid Coronavirus Shutdown, Museum Director 'Incredibly Pissed'
item.description: On Monday, a Dutch museum announced that a painting by Vincent Van Gogh was missing after thieves broke into the building in an early-morning raid. Lentetuin, painted by Van Gogh in the spring of 1884, was on loan to the Singer Laren museum, which closed its doors earlier this month due to the risks of COVID-19.

item.title: Teen Who Died Of COVID-19 Was Denied Treatment Because He Didn't Have Health Insurance
item.description: Roughly 27.5 million Americans — 8.5 percent of the population — don't have health insurance based on the latest government figures.

item.title: Space Force To Get The Hell Off Of Earth
item.description: The US Space Force is scheduled to launch its first mission to space on Thursday from Cape Canaveral, sending a communications satellite into orbit aboard a United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket.
item.kicker: MAY THE FORCE BE WITH YOU

item.title: Android Apps May Be Snooping On You More Than You Realize
item.description: It's not as simple as tracking where you go and what you do in an app: apps might be dropping details about the other programs you've installed on your phone, too.

item.title: These 19 Apps Will Help You Social Distance Without Feeling Isolated
item.description: Most of us are stuck inside because of the extraordinary circumstances we currently find ourselves in. Fortunately, self-quarantine doesn't require a total lack of communication with the outside.

item.title: Scientists Find A Superconductor In Bits Of Meteorite
item.description: The superconductor inside the Australian meteorite is a known material, but the discovery itself comes as a shock.

item.title: Smart Thermometers Could Be Key To Tracking The Coronavirus, For Better Or Worse
item.description: When it comes to tracking the spread of one of the worst pandemics in recent memory, personal privacy has taken a bit of a backburner.

item.title: What's The Softest Thing?
item.description: There are a lot of soft things out there: cats, infants, expertly-laundered sweaters. What if there was some kind of omniscient softness guide, ranking every item in the universe in order of softness?

item.title: 'Cats' Is A 'Medieval Morality Play': 20 Highlights From Tom Hooper's Director Commentary
item.description: "Cats" has finally come home, and we've combed through the director commentary to uncover the film's greatest secrets. It may be one of those movies that's impossible to explain, but director Tom Hooper was determined to try.
item.kicker: OH, YOU THOUGHT WE WERE DONE WITH 'CATS'?

item.title: The Mutant That Set Off A Seedless Gold Rush
item.description: Despite repeated maladies that have threatened their existence, navel oranges continue to brighten our fruit bowls. They're the seedless mutants that are too delicious to let die.

item.title: Here's What Apple Would Have Announced At Its Canceled March Event
item.description: For starters, Apple announced today it's got a new iPad Pro and an updated MacBook Air. And based on the deets, both launches basically confirm recent rumors that the iPad Pro was due for a refresh, and that butterfly keyboards were on their way out.

item.title: Discovery In Mexico Sheds New Light On Ancient Ballgame
item.description: Mesoamericans living thousands of years ago participated in a ballgame that carried tremendous social, political, and spiritual importance.

item.title: How To Access All Your Files When You Have To Work From Home
item.description: Many of us are now working from home for the time being, which can be both challenging and invigorating. But it can also be a pain when you have multiple devices.

item.title: Chelsea Manning Attempted Suicide In Jail, Is Recovering, Lawyers Say
item.description: Imprisoned activist and former Army intelligence analyst Chelsea Manning attempted suicide on Wednesday in the Alexandria, Virginia, jail where she's been held for a year following her refusal to testify before a federal grand jury investigating WikiLeaks.

item.title: 'The Weirdest Fossil I've Ever Been Lucky Enough To Study': Skull Found In Amber Reveals Tiny Toothed Bird
item.description: The tiny skull of a hummingbird-size dinosaur has been found trapped in amber, raising important questions about the evolution of birds and the surprisingly early trend toward miniaturization.

item.title: Why Does Ketamine Work For Depression When Nothing Else Does?
item.description: Even though depression is a common and debilitating mental illness, the last groundbreaking medication released for it was Prozac, approved in 1987.

item.title: Why Won't The World Health Organization Call This A Pandemic?
item.description: We're not on the brink of a pandemic anymore — we're in the middle of one.
item.kicker: HOW MUCH LONGER DO WE HAVE TO WAIT

item.title: Is Mold Dangerous?
item.description: Pretty much everyone can agree that mold looks disgusting. But does this colonizing fungus, beyond its surface-level repellence, actually mean us harm?

item.title: One Of The Rarest Video Game Consoles Of All Time Just Sold For $360,000 At Auction
item.description: A failed partnership 28 years ago between a pair of gigantic names in gaming has resulted in one of the rarest pieces of hardware in video game history selling at auction today for a staggering $360,000—and it doesn't even include a single game.
item.kicker: AND YOU CAN'T EVEN PLAY IT

item.title: How Humanity Could Last Forever
item.description: Our species will face no shortage of existential risks in the coming decades. Can we sidestep them and carry on?
item.kicker: DON'T WANNA LIVE LIKE THIS, BUT DON'T WANNA DIE

item.title: Cryonics, Dakota The Dog And The Hope Of Forever
item.description: Most families chose traditional dispositions like burial or cremation for their pets. Less frequently, they may choose something untraditional, like taxidermy. This would be the first time we've ever worked with clients who requested cryogenic preservation.

item.title: New Study Finds That Moviegoers Are Exposed To Toxic 'Thirdhand Smoke' From The Clothing Of Smokers
item.description: Simply sitting in a cinema to watch a movie can expose people to the equivalent of one to 10 cigarettes' worth of secondhand smoke, according to a new chemical analysis.
item.kicker: THOUGHT YOU MIGHT NEED SOME MORE BAD NEWS

item.title: Hot Damn, Look At The Batmobile From The New 'Batman' Movie
item.description: You've seen his new suit, but who would the Dark Knight be without a fancy set of wheels to prowl Gotham's streets in?

item.title: Here's Every New Coronavirus Case Reported In The US Over The Past 24 Hours
item.description: The US reported 21 new coronavirus cases during the past 24 hours, as the number of infected continues to climb.

item.title: I Went To CPAC To See How Conservatives Think Big Tech Is Censoring Them
item.description: Republican voters largely buy Donald Trump's claims that social media is trying to hound right-wingers off the internet. But it isn't clear what evidence they have other than a gut feeling.

item.title: What Would It Take To End HIV Forever?
item.description: Many public health experts believe it possible to effectively eradicate the disease by 2030. It'll take lots of work, though, and we're not getting off to the right start.

item.title: Many States Still Can't Test Locally For Coronavirus
item.description: New York and Florida reported their first cases overnight. But many states still can't conduct tests for the coronavirus locally, despite the federal government's promise last week to quickly ship out tests.
item.kicker: 89 PEOPLE IN TWO STATES ARE AFFECTED

item.title: Will My Data Be Online Forever?
item.description: We've all pretty much reconciled ourselves to the fact that a handful of unaccountable technology executives have all our data. But how long will they hang onto it?

item.title: GoodRx Shared My Prescription Data With Third Parties — And It's Perfectly Legal
item.description: With the abysmal state of healthcare, it shouldn't be surprising that tech companies have swooped to solve the ills that the federal government can't or won't.

item.title: All The Forensic Science You See Presented In Court In The Movies Is Utterly Unscientific
item.description: You know when a TV detective finds a hair on a crime scene and matches DNA from the hair to a database to find the criminal? As with most things, the real-life analog is a lot more complicated and less sexy. There's actually no scientific research that supports the reliability of methods like hair-matching — not to mention that no case should ride on evidence that could well have been inadvertently tampered with in a careless lab.

item.title: Why Is Courtroom Science So Unscientific?
item.description: While it's now widely accepted that some forensic methods, like microscopic hair comparison, are junk science, evidence from similarly subjective areas still gets into courtrooms.

item.title: 'The High Republic,' A New Era Of Star Wars Storytelling, Is Here
item.description: "For over a thousand generations, the Jedi Knights were the guardians of peace and justice in the Old Republic. Before the dark times, before the Empire."
item.kicker: IN A GALAXY NOT SO FAR AWAY

item.title: 11 Horror Movies Featuring Creepy, Haunted Apartments
item.description: Haunted houses may get all the attention, but apartment buildings can give off some terrifying energy, too — whether it's in the form of something that follows you in, or something that pounces once you've signed your lease.

item.title: One Woman And Thousands Of Lego Bricks Are Building A Town Much-Needed Wheelchair Ramps
item.description: In an effort to undo decades of design that's made spaces inaccessible to those with mobility challenges, 62-year old Rita Ebel is spending part building wheelchair ramps out of colorful Lego bricks.
